fields.value: Replication Data for: Intuitive Ethics and Political Orientations: Testing Moral Foundations as a Theory of Political Ideology

dsDescriptionValue.value: Originally developed to explain cultural variation in moral judgments, moral foundations theory (MFT) has become widely adopted as a theory of political ideology. MFT posits that political attitudes are rooted in instinctual evaluations generated by innate psychological modules evolved to solve social dilemmas. If this is correct, moral foundations must be relatively stable dispositional traits, changes in moral foundations should systematically predict consequent changes in political orientations, and at least in part, be heritable. We test these hypotheses and find substantial variability in individual-level moral foundations across time, and little evidence that these changes account for changes in political attitudes. We also find little evidence that moral foundations are heritable.  These findings raise questions about the future of MFT as a theory of ideology

publicationCitation.value: Smith, Kevin B., John R. Alford, John R. Hibbing, Nicholas G. Martin, and Peter K. Hatemi. "Intuitive Ethics and Political Orientations: Testing Moral Foundations as a Theory of Political Ideology." American Journal of Political Science.

fields.value:
This dataset underwent an independent verification process that replicated the tables and figures in the primary article. For the supplementary materials, verification was performed solely for the successful execution of code. The verification process was carried out by the Odum Institute for Research in Social Science at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

Note: The Odum Institute verification team found different p-values for the chi-square difference test in Table 3 from the authors. This may be due to a version change from Mplus 6 to Mplus 7; however, this does not impact the conclusion or primary findings presented in the article.

The associated article has been awarded Open Materials and Open Data Badges. Learn more about the Open Practice Badges from the Center for Open Science.

files.description:
Data File for Twin Analyses.
We highly recommend that interested persons create a new dat file for twin analyses based on their own interest. That is create a file based on the primary data set. We supplied our dat file for the twin analyses to allow for perfect replication and to make it easier for others to see the results and play with different configurations , dropping parameters, etc.  But twin analyses can be as much art as science, and what you put in is what you get out.  How one creates a factor score, sum scores, drops items, listwise versus casewise deletion, the choice of stats package, method, starting values, and thousands of others decisions that are analyst specific may change the results.
files.label: DF6.TwinJun27.dat

files.description: This file contains the variable coding, and scripts for the correlations, factor analyses, and reliability analyses in SPSS and can reproduce Tables 1, 2, S2, S3, S4, S6, S7, S8, S9, S10. The data to use with this script is DF1.Australian.Primary.Phenotypic.data.sav. Please email Kevin Smith for any questions on this script or these analyses.

files.description: The file S2.US.replication.samples.script  contains the variable coding, and scripts for the correlations, factor analyses, and reliability analyses for the three US replication studies. The script is in SPSS and can reproduce Table S5. The data to use with this script is Moral_Foundations.sav, Moral_Foundations11Oct.sav, Moral_Foundations28Oct. sav. Please email Kevin Smith for any questions on this script or these analyses.
files.label: S2.US.replication.samples.script.sps

files.description: These files contain the scripts to the run the cross lag correlation analyses for Table 3, S11 and S12.   The data to use with this script is SEMOCT26.dat.  For the Cross lagged analyses there are several steps- the script needs to be changed to run the diff test- To make it easier for replication we simply created two separate scripts for each analysis. The first step (run1) is to run the script that generates the output data and the diff test data.  Use the estimates from this output.  The second step requires the script be edited to a) not generate a new difftest file, b) fix the causal paths so we can c) compare to the difftest data .  We now have two scripts for each labeled run1 and run2 respectively. Take the estimates from run1, use run2 to test for significance (see chi sq diff test in the out file). Please email Pete Hatemi for any questions on these scripts analyses.
files.label: S3.Bind.CL.run1.inp

files.description: These files contain the SEM scripts to run the analyses for Figures 1,2. The data to use with this script is SEMOCT26.dat . To run the analyses for each factor individually (S1-S5) simply adjust the use variables and model section with the reduced MF items. See comments in the script. Please email Pete Hatemi for any questions on these scripts or analyses.

files.description:
This Zip file contains 23 scripts to the run the twin analyses. We strongly suggest that interested persons create a new .dat file based on the Primary data set.  We supplied our premade .dat file for the twin analyses to make it easier for others to replicate our work. But in order to play with different configurations it is advised to create a new stacked data file for your own purposes. Twin analyses can be as much art as science, and what you put in is what you get out.  How one creates a factor score, sum scores, drops items, listwise versus casewise deletion, the choice of stats package, method, starting values, dropping parameters, adding constraints, and so forth,  and thousands of other decisions that are analyst specific may change the results.

The scripts short names in the Zip file are mostly intuitive but please open each script to find the full description on the first line (see “! SCRIPT NAME”) – the name will correspond to the traits analyzed for Table 4 and S10. The data to use with these scripts is DF6.TwinJun27.dat.  To run the scripts, simply change the name of the dat file by removing the “DF6.Twin” from the file name so the file name is Jun27.dat or Change each script to call DF6.Twin. Jun27.dat- buyers choice here. As stated above we used the more lengthy label since we have many data sets. The varnames are listed in the file DD3.Data.Dictionary.Twin.Analyses.
files.label: S9.MXScripts.7z
